issue.title: Fix a bug where intrinsics were ignored when compiling for apple silicon
issue.body:
<!-- Please give a brief explanation of the purpose of this pull request. -->
This pr fixes an issue for apple silicon compile-time feature detection.

<!-- Does this PR resolve any issue?  If so, please reference it using automatic-closing keywords like "Fixes #123." -->
Replaces #1073.

comment.body:
> Just to clarify, do you mean the c code, or intrinsics code? When testing on the Apple Silicon machine with this change it used intrinsics for me. I did have to specify not to use openssl with `-DOQS_USE_OPENSSL=OFF` in order for the intrinsics to be used.

I compiled with `cmake -GNinja -DOQS_USE_OPENSSL=OFF ..` and the intrinsics code was used.

I would have that compiling with just `cmake -GNinja ..` would cause OpenSSL to be used for SHA2 (and indeed that seems to be what's happening in a build I just tried).  Are you experiencing something different?

issue.title: SSH server start question
issue.body:
Hello, this is just a question. I keep getting "sshd: no hostkeys available -- exiting." but I store my keys in ~/home/user/.ssh and I use this command to start the server "{opensshDir}./sshd -D -f {opensshDir}/sshd_config -o KexAlgorithms=kyber-512-sha256 -o HostKeyAlgorithms=ssh-dilithium3 -o PubkeyAcceptedKeyTypes=ssh-dilithium3 -h /home/user/.ssh/id-dilithium3"

Is there something that I am missing or I am doing wrong? As I am unable to figure out how to get it started.

comment.body: I don't recall ever trying to run it in that configuration.  To be clear you're trying to use the server (host) key from your home directory?

issue.title: inline keyword in SIKE
issue.body: SIKE uses `__inline` to mark some inline code, but this appears to be an MSVC-specific keyword.  The more portable way seems to be either `inline` or `__inline__`, although there are some subtle differences between these two that I'm not entirely sure of.  @christianpaquin do you know if `__inline` was chosen for a specific reason?

comment.body: FYI, I'll take a look at this when I'm back at the keyboard, starting next week.

issue.title: Namespacing of SIKE constants
issue.body:
Compiling liboqs with SIKEp503-compressed enabled and SIKEp503 disabled (e.g. by compiling with `-DOQS_MINIMAL_BUILD=ON -DOQS_KEM_DEFAULT=OQS_KEM_alg_sike_p503_compressed`) results in undefined symbols at link time:
```
/usr/bin/ld: src/kem/sike/CMakeFiles/sike.dir/external/P503/AMD64/fp_x64_asm.S.o: relocation R_X86_64_PC32 against undefined symbol `oqs_kem_sike_p503x2' can not be used when making a shared object; recompile with -fPIC
```

This is because of some namespacing that we add to the upstream code.

Both P503.c and P503_compressed.c define a symbol called `p503x2`. To avoid redefinition errors when building both parameter sets, we have some #defines that turn `p503x2` into `oqs_kem_sike_p503x2` and `oqs_kem_sike_compressed_p503x2`.

The problem is that `fp_x64_asm.S` only ever looks for `oqs_kem_sike_p503x2`: 
```asm
    #define fmt(f)    oqs_kem_sike_##f
    [...]
    mov    rcx, [rip+fmt(p503x2)]
```

I suggest moving the constants from P503.c and P503_compressed.c to a new compilation unit. This will avoid the redefinition problem and reduce code size.

comment.body: FYI, I'll take a look at this when I'm back at the keyboard, starting next week.

issue.title: SSH server start question
issue.body:
Hello, this is just a question. I keep getting "sshd: no hostkeys available -- exiting." but I store my keys in ~/home/user/.ssh and I use this command to start the server "{opensshDir}./sshd -D -f {opensshDir}/sshd_config -o KexAlgorithms=kyber-512-sha256 -o HostKeyAlgorithms=ssh-dilithium3 -o PubkeyAcceptedKeyTypes=ssh-dilithium3 -h /home/user/.ssh/id-dilithium3"

Is there something that I am missing or I am doing wrong? As I am unable to figure out how to get it started.

comment.body: Yes. Should I move them to regress?

issue.title: Fix a bug where intrinsics were ignored when compiling for apple silicon
issue.body:
<!-- Please give a brief explanation of the purpose of this pull request. -->
This pr fixes an issue for apple silicon compile-time feature detection.

<!-- Does this PR resolve any issue?  If so, please reference it using automatic-closing keywords like "Fixes #123." -->
Replaces #1073.

comment.body:
> I would have that compiling with just cmake -GNinja .. would cause OpenSSL to be used for SHA2

This is exactly what should happen. Anything else would be incorrect/unintended behaviour of the system.

I'd approve this PR if someone could point to documentation stating that all Apple ARM64 platforms have optimized SHA2 instructions.

issue.body:
Hello, this is just a question. I keep getting "sshd: no hostkeys available -- exiting." but I store my keys in ~/home/user/.ssh and I use this command to start the server "{opensshDir}./sshd -D -f {opensshDir}/sshd_config -o KexAlgorithms=kyber-512-sha256 -o HostKeyAlgorithms=ssh-dilithium3 -o PubkeyAcceptedKeyTypes=ssh-dilithium3 -h /home/user/.ssh/id-dilithium3"

Is there something that I am missing or I am doing wrong? As I am unable to figure out how to get it started.

comment.body:
> I am unable to figure out how to get it started.

Can you please post the output you're getting? A `mv` to regress doesn't sound like a good solution.

comment.body:
> this isn't apple technical documentation, this PR on google's CPU features detection tool says that all apple chips since the A7 have the crypto extensions: google/cpu_features#150 (comment)

Given Apple purportedly doesn't give technical documentation to it's own engineers without NDA that's probably as good as it gets :-)

issue.title: SSH server start question
issue.body:
Hello, this is just a question. I keep getting "sshd: no hostkeys available -- exiting." but I store my keys in ~/home/user/.ssh and I use this command to start the server "{opensshDir}./sshd -D -f {opensshDir}/sshd_config -o KexAlgorithms=kyber-512-sha256 -o HostKeyAlgorithms=ssh-dilithium3 -o PubkeyAcceptedKeyTypes=ssh-dilithium3 -h /home/user/.ssh/id-dilithium3"

Is there something that I am missing or I am doing wrong? As I am unable to figure out how to get it started.

comment.body:
I followed the script and no additional parameters were passed to ./configure. 

The following script was used to create the keys 
./ssh-keygen -t ssh-dilithium3
This by default saves it to .ssh

**I wrote the server code in a python script** 
pi@pi:~/openssh/code$ python3 server.py 
Unable to load host key: /home/pi/.ssh/id-dilithium3
sshd: no hostkeys available -- exiting.

issue.title: SSH server start question
issue.body:
Hello, this is just a question. I keep getting "sshd: no hostkeys available -- exiting." but I store my keys in ~/home/user/.ssh and I use this command to start the server "{opensshDir}./sshd -D -f {opensshDir}/sshd_config -o KexAlgorithms=kyber-512-sha256 -o HostKeyAlgorithms=ssh-dilithium3 -o PubkeyAcceptedKeyTypes=ssh-dilithium3 -h /home/user/.ssh/id-dilithium3"

Is there something that I am missing or I am doing wrong? As I am unable to figure out how to get it started.

comment.body: Are you using the (host key file) name "id_dilithium3" (underscore: keygen-default) or "id-dilithium3" (hypen/dash: Wouldn't be found)?

comment.body:
Just caught that error and corrected the python script. Unfortunately, I am getting additional errors: 

**Modified code:**
{opensshDir}./sshd -D -f {opensshDir}/sshd_config -o KexAlgorithms=kyber-512-sha256 -o HostKeyAlgorithms=ssh_dilithium3 -o PubkeyAcceptedKeyTypes=ssh_dilithium3 -h /home/pi/.ssh/ssh_dilithium3

comment.body: Same question (again :-) More seriously: You may want to check the permissible key type names (e.g., in `sshkey.c`).

issue.title: Documentation: add the ability to jump into different sections
issue.body:
In the html generated documentation, the links to different sections on the same page don't work.
It seems to be possible to do this though, by using something like: http://doxygen.10944.n7.nabble.com/Creating-links-in-and-between-Markdown-files-pages-td6689.html

Though, this might break the markdown links...

comment.body: I didn't find a way so far of doing it: it is either the html or markdown. So, I think it is good to close.
